starts with original research articles on values in health care priority setting (by Claudia Landwehr and Dorothea Klinnert), on the role of hospital payments in the adoption of new medical technologies (by Corinna Sorenson, Michael Drummond, Aleksandra Torbica, Giuditta Callea and Ceu Mateus), and on preferences for lifestyle interventions to reduce obesity (by Mandy Ryan, Deokhee Yi, Alison Avenell, Flora Douglas, Lorna Aucott, Edwin van Teijlingen and Luke Vale). The programme will begin with some words about HEPL from Patrick McCartan of Cambridge University Press.<br><br>There will then be short statements from some of the members of HEPL's International Advisory Board on what they think the biggest challenges will be in health care policy, either from the perspective of their own country or internationally, over the next 10 years. Architecture? I don't think the Prince of<br> [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-07T11:39:55+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Calum Paton</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AAHPN;93182f52.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AAHPN;724a7888.1501">   <title>The UK general election and the row over Labour's health policy in England </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AAHPN;724a7888.1501</link>   <description> There is currently a row within the Labour Party in the UK, with the<br>general election approaching, over English health policy. So-called<br>Blairites such as former Health Secretary (1999-2003) Alan Milburn have<br>attacked party policy to make the NHS the 'preferred provider' as opposed<br>to having mandatory tendering of every service, open to private providers<br>both national and international. That is, Milburn and others seem to<br>support the Health and Social Care Act of 2012, following former<br>Conservative Health Secretary (2010-2012) Andrew Lansley's White paper of<br>2010. It is Labour policy to repeal this.
